I was in Yangon in 2021 for a few weeks on a work contract. At the time, the Myanmar embassy in my country was refusing to recognize the military junta and wasn't issuing work visas, so my organization flew me to Thailand and I got a visa from there and then flew in on a plane that was 90% cargo (most of the passenger seats had been removed).
The situation was very tense during that time. Only a couple of ATMs were stocked with cash every day. There were shootings and bombings going on, which I never saw personally but did see in videos posted to a Signal exapt group. We were warned by my worker not to talk politics with any local and to be careful if someone tried to chat us up because they might be military. I'm quite sure that one day a friendly guy in a restaurant was in fact military because he was badmouthing the junta, trying to get me to talk about it, and the other locals avoided him.
We were supposed to stay in a hotel compound when we weren't being driven to and from work, but nothing stopped us from coming and going before the citywide curfew. I left a few times to walk around and search for some stuff I wanted to buy. Before the creampie guy asks, yes, I did get a hooker too. I noticed there was one young woman who was always outside and one evening I walked up to her and exchanged Line info. We chatted over Line and we worked out a deal where she visited my hotel. She was more than happy to get US dollars.
If you go, you should bring a large amount of US currency, "new" bills in good condition, 100s and 20s. (It sounds like a pain, but the more 20s you bring the better, and keep them in the pages of a book to preserve their condition. You'll literally get 10% better black market rates (which everyone used when i was there, even the legit FX kiosks) for good condition bills, and a higher rate for 100 bills than lower denominations. I say bring a lot of 20s because anything of value you want to buy will be much cheaper in USD.

threads.name: Walking Tanzanian
threads.com:
So I'm thinking of leaving tomorrow and trek through my country, Tanzania. Any advice on cross-country walking? I'll leave my phone and everything behind. Carry a backpack and a few clothes and some things to lie on and cover myself, a container for food I buy along the way, and a 2 Litre bottle of water. I'll post a don't worry message on Twitter, and have about $2000 in my bank account(which is a lot in Tanzania) and will be withdrawing little by little at ATMs.

Why am I doing this? After my last suicide attempt life has been feeling pointless. I dropped out of university and have been blaming myself for not making the suicide work. I always believe the universe is so big, you can choose to minimize your gaze and focus on the little you can control, or expand your horizons and explore. I've done the former for so long and it hasn't left me satisfied, might as well try the latter for a change. I hope in this journey I find a reason to live, or a reason not to, but regardless, I owe myself to try.

I'm currently in Bukoba(picrel), I'm thinking of following the paved trunk roads and sleeping alongside it all the way to Dar es salaam. I'll try to stay at most 2 days without food before I consider taking a small bus to the closest town.

Anyway. Any advice on cross-country walking?

I have multiple friends living as expats in the Netherlands, and most of them complain a lot. The Dutch are very blunt to the point of being rude, and most are disinterested in socializing with foreigners. Although they have some of the best English in Europe it's typical for most to speak only Dutch if there's more than one Dutch person present. You'll probably wind up in a mostly if not entirely-expat bubble. That's not necessarily a bad thing, but it's a thing.

All that said, as a casual visitor I've always had a good time there. You might give it a shot if you can get a company to sponsor you for a work permit (as above seething poster suggests, it's basically impossible for an American to move to Europe without having a job in hand before departure; it's rare to be allowed to come over first and seek work on the ground, and if you try to go that route anyway, you will almost certainly have to leave the country again to get your papers in order at an embassy outside of NL once you have an offer in hand).

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2367167
>Even if you were married to a Dutch girl you wouldn't be able to work there
>wtf? why?
The Dutch just have a slightly tighter version of the universal EU labor law. For an employer to hire a foreigner, first they have to prove that there is no Dutch national available who could do the job. Next they have to prove that there’s nobody from elsewhere in the EU who could do the job. So Americans and all other non-EU foreigners are a distant third in line. Plus, alongside the bureaucratic PITA, it’s much more expensive to import non-EU people, so even if the protectionist policies didn’t exist there would be a big disincentive to bother hiring Yanks.

Not to say that it doesn’t happen. But it happens even less than in other EU countries. You’ve basically either got to be pretty hot shit or get transferred in with a multinational.

>>2366769
I'm the samefag who lives in India. I own a motorbike and recently took a 3,500kms trip across East-Central India. I work remotely and typically need stable internet access every day, so I can't really stay in bottom-of-the-barrel hotels when I'm traveling.

However, finding inexpensive options isn't particularly difficult, although you might struggle to find hotels that accept foreign guests in isolated or rural areas. IME, this has far less to do with xenophobia than the Indian government's requirement that hotels file reports--Form C--whenever they host foreign guests. These reports have to be filed with the nearest police station within 24 hours of the guest's arrival.

Nowadays, hotels and guesthouses can fill out Form C online, but you still have to create an account and spend about ~5 minutes entering the traveler's information. A lot of lower-budget facilities either don't know how to do it or receive so few foreign guests that they won't bother.

Nevertheless, you can typically find homestays and budget hotels for $5-$12 per night, depending on the area and amenities. It's typically best to search options in advance, since showing up in town and searching for a place doesn't always work out. Booking.com and other aggregators will usually indicate whether a property allows foreign guests in its "Property Rules" section.

>I've met a few people who've done it, but they say it's not that great
I quite enjoy moto-touring in India. The traffic is actually quite manageable outside of urban areas. If you avoid large, high-volume motorways, you'll often be the only one on the road (with the exception of other motorbikes, cyclists, and the occasional auto-rickshaw).

>>2360364
I know Madrid has been mentioned already, but Barcelona is by FAR my favourite city in the world to stay in, especially long term. I'm eventually planning on moving there.

For me, Barcelona is the perfect mix of a big, industrial modern cosmopolitan city, with beautiful historic architecture and a refreshing combination of both chilled out beach/party/tourist elements and normal every-day working life.

Madrid is very similar, except a more conservative, more administrative city with far less touristic/party elements. For me, I could explore Barcelona for several weeks, seeing new parts of the city, meeting people from all over the world, visiting interesting museums, relaxing at different beaches and eating at different types of restaurants and not get bored. I could probably only do the same in Madrid for several days.

Honestly, I don't have a single negative thing to say about Barcelona.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2367058
To be honest, you will struggle because accessibility infrastructure is very basic and sometimes plain dysfunctional.
For example in Samarkand, you'll be able to visit the Registan complex and the Gur Emir mausoleum without problems, but places like the Shahi-Zinda necropolis will require you to climb stairs like pic related.
Stairs in general will be a problem, many of them are steep, uneven or crooked and they rarely have handrails.

However, the locals are very helpful, especially if you look like you're having difficulties plus it's still cheap enough to hire a private guide+driver, so you'll be able t dictate the pace and only exhaust yourself where it cannot be avoided.

Best water I saw was probably Gramvousa Island, which also has a kickass venetian fortress on it, its a hard walk up thetr but honestly some jaw dropping views, then a nice beach you can snorkel in, (I brought my own snorkel which I got for cheap at a supermarket) absolutely crystal clear waters. I had a day tour from a boat and also on the same day visited balos lagoon which is really incredible, well worth taking a hike up the hill there to take in the panorama after a swim, my god so beautiful.

You can also go by bus or car to balos but roads are really shitty, boat is better imo. Any tourist place in crete will be settling boat tickets, take a look and think about it. I just got a taxi to the ferry terminal and had a good time

Otherwise, if you've not hiked samaria gorge do it, it's incredible, can be busy but fuck, such a good experience. I definitely recommend hiring a hiking stick though, they will offer it, just do it. Then you end up at a clear blue water beach at the end, there's no sand and the rocks are boiling hot on your feet but once you're in the water makes to for it. Also there's tavernas and stuff is you just want to eat. The goat meat is very tasty

I also went to elafonsi beach which is also gorgeous but very busy and full of instathots, but if you're snorkeling who gives a fuck.

Threat are all pretty known sights in crete, I usually avoid local travel agents but in this case maybe worth it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2366676
I have some experience with programs affiliated with the DRH Movement / Humana People to People. They've been running in some form or another since the 1970's. The template is some period of time doing studies/training in Europe or the US, some period of time working in a development project in Africa, and some shorter period of time concluding back in Europe or the US. Currently, it looks like it's 3 months study/prep/training, 6 months at the project, 1 month conclusion.

The work you do at the project will partly depend on your preferences and partly on what's available. I worked in the country office for an HIV prevention program, where I helped with training community health outreach workers and led a knowledge-attitudes-practices survey team. My wife worked with a program for expanding access to clean water in rural areas.

In the past I would have a bit of hesitation to recommend these programs, because the training period used to be 6 months and involved some unpleasant shit. It looks like they just eliminated the bad parts and kept the rest, which is great.

You will run into annoying "save the world" types. You might be one of them. You will also run into people who are doing the program as a fun experience or for their resumes. That's just the type of people who do this stuff.

If you're interested, there are a few different DRH schools running this program-- One World Center in Michigan in the US, College for International Co-Operation and Development in England, Richmond Vale Academy in St. Vincent, DRH Lindersvold in Denmark, and maybe one or two more in Denmark that I've left out.

>>2366528
>Have you ever been to Denali National park?
Yup, road to Fairbanks goes through DNP. The park itself is actually quite large, and the mountain is not near the tourist zone (which is on the highway). If you want to go the mountain, typically you'd either drive on the backroads (they're dirt mostly I thinK), or take a park bus. There are 1 or 2 resorts there, and they'll have electricity, running water, internet, etc. They're quite expensive though ($300+/night?). The tourist zone only operates in summer months; complete ghost town in the winter (also wouldn't recommend driving the road between anchorage/fairbanks in the winter unless you're experienced, it's remote, no cell connection, and cold, ie dangerous.
>How affordable is it to visit Alaska?
Assuming leaving from SF, LA, Seattle, or Portland, round trip flight to anchorage is like $400 economy? Hotels are probably cheaper than what you'd find in downtown major cities in US, maybe $80-$200/night. Food is probably slightly more expensive than any other metro US area. Though, significantly cheaper than other northern cities you'd find in canada, europe, etc. Attractions are mostly outdoors and free, though I believe DNP requires a park pass? Not sure, one isn't needed if you stay in tourist/highway corridor. Rental cars are expensive as fuck. Like $100/day or more.
Public transit outside of the Anchorage and Fairbanks metro areas is basically non-existent, with the exception of the Alaska Railroad, which you should probably look into. It's not super cheap, but it operates all along the Seward Highway, through Anchorage and up to DNP and to Fairbanks. They have sleeper cabins, food, etc.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2366333

Not an expert (or avid train rider) but can answer some.

>If you go interstate by train, how long in advance should you book tickets?

They are not very busy, so I imagine you could probably book them at the station. I looked up one from brisbane to sydney and I could book the next one in 2 days.

>Why do some flights between capitals cost less than some trains/ferries?

Because planes are a much cheaper and faster alternative than trains for the large distances between Australian cities, why would you get 13hr train when you could get a 1hr 30min flight?

>Are busses a better option than trains?

Cheaper, but again 15-23hr trip vs 1hr 30min flight

>What occurs at interstate checkpoints and how much time is wasted at them?

As far as I know, generally there are no checkpoints (there was during covid), though in more rural areas they might check produce/animals.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
In my experience you don't need to book far in advance. Might be different for something touristy in peak season, like the Ghan in winter.
Flights are heavily used in Australia so they just scale better. Only really applies if you book far enough in advance, plenty of over priced bullshit.
My personal preference is always trains but it just depends on where you're going, consider the price and duration of the trip.
There are no interstate check points, we're a federation. There was briefly checkpoints in place during Covid-19 restrictions but that's long over.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
This thread is dedicated to the discussion of airlines and major international airports.

I'm looking to go to Prague from the US this spring and my three main options are Lufthansa, KLM, and LOT. My assumption is that Lufthansa is the best but they all seem be equally mediocre according to the slew of tripadvisor reviews I've seen. So far I have flown internationally with United, American, EVA, British, Iberia, and ANA. So far EVA was the best in my opinion but I think I have bias due to the cutie flight attendants. All the American and European airlines seem to be on par with each other so should I just go with the cheapest? Right now, LOT is about $100 cheaper but something about them seems off. All advice and discussion is welcomed.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>LH, KLM, LOT
Yep, take the one that is the most convenient/cheapest.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I went to Prague from the US twice this year. The first time was an American Airlines/British Air ticket and the second was Icelandair from US to London then British Air from London to Prague.

In my experience with international flights, the services are almost identical unless you pay significantly less or significantly more. Personally I prefer to go with the "top tier" airlines because I figure they have more money to put into maintenance and training, and they pay more for priority at airport gates so you don't have to sit on the tarmac as long.

On my first trip I got rerouted through Munich on Lufthansa and the service was great - they knew the flight was late so for the transfer in Munich they already had vans waiting to take people to their other flights as quickly as possible, didn't even go into the airport.

In the long run, $100-200 extra on a ticket is chump change and it's worth it to avoid stupid layovers or red eye flights or budget airlines etc. etc.

In southern California, the wineries in Temecula do wine tastings. For $25 at each winery, you get four 1 ounce cups. That's less than a glass of wine for $25. Up north in Napa, a lot of places charge $40 or more for those tastings.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2363061
Simply put OP, you have to think of Asia as a kind of spectrum of cultures and wealthiness. If you want your trip to be interesting as a beginner, you'd be well inspired to visit the extremes first, and the more nuanced countries later. China and Japan for example have two very different cultures whereas Korea and Taiwan are a nuance of the former.
Vietnam and Thailand are the bigger cultural and economic actors of the ex-indochina region and thus visiting laos and cambodia would just be a waste of time for now.
The three outliers are the philippines (due to it being simply unique), and Indonesia/malaysia (visiting one of em is enough, the other one's basically the same). If you're planning to do a long trip with multiple countries, you should definitely do both in one swing, like say Japan and Vietnam or China and Thailand. Or Japan and Thailand, since China hasn't opened yet.

I also suggest you start with the poorer country first, since third world countries have some inconveniences i'm sure you'll figure out, and by going to the more developed country after that it'll allow your body and mind to take a break from the hustle and bustle. This being said, it all hinges on how much time you have. If 2 weeks is all you have you can honestly just stay in Japan for the duration of the trip. You'd save more money that way to do more interesting stuff.

The upside to this is that a natural equilibrium has come up for tourism to flourish. Recognizing that without foreign cash we're fucked, gangs near tourist areas have come to a tacit agreement of "we won't fuck with tourists, but you don't intrude on our drug business, even if tourists blatantly come to us for drugs" with the gov. Old San Juan has the La Perla ghetto, one of the most famous drug and crime hotspots in the island. You can hang around the wall that borders it in complete safety, but if you descend down into the ghetto itself then you either buy and gtfo or go at your own risk. The rest of old san juan is safe and holds a regular police presence, they just won't go into the ghetto itself unless serious shit goes down. Same with Condado which has its ghettoes far from nightlife. La Placita is a bit more of a hotspot but there's a big police and even undercover cop presence there. The other main spots in Rio Grande, Fajardo, Humacao, Rincon and La Parguera are more rural and don't have as big of a gang conflict issue since there's more territory for less people, and tourists are kept encapsulated in bubbles created by resorts and guarded by private security. Palmas del Mar in Humacao is great, all rich people, multiple gated communities, private police roaming constantly... It's solid. You really only need to worry about safety as a tourist in the metro area, but the main hubs are safe and tourists won't go out of their way to enter the shittier parts of the metro area like Carolina. Drugs are directly linked to around 60% of all murders in PR, drugs basically cause the majority of violence. South America simply loves shipping to and through us. Since we buy direct, it's great for dealers. Colombians can sell us a brick for under a grand but we can flip it for $12k-17k so a loss of product is quickly paid back to the point where losing half of your batch is a negligible loss since profit margins are so comparably high.

>US Style access to guns
Nope. We had one of, if not THE strictest gun control laws in America. Before the latest USSC ruling, I would have to get a license for sport from the police. Originally these cost a whopping $500 per application, required you to pay for a membership at a shooting range and involved a multiple months long waiting period plus background check. If you were granted the license (it was not a guarantee) you got the right to only RENT a gun at a range for the purpose of shooting for sport at that range and nothing else. You could not purchase a gun to be kept at the range. Once you had the license for sport you then had to apply for a carry license which cost about $1,000, included the background check, a certified safety and handling class you also had to pay separately for, required sworn affidavits and approval by a judge instead of police, needed two people who knew you to confirm your good character and even if all requirements were met you could still be told no. That's all for the license alone btw, you buy the gun alone after. It effectively cost you $1500 and 4-12 months for a license then however many hundreds or thousands the gun cost. Almost no one had legal access to guns in PR until 2020.
>geography allows easy drugs
That's the ticket. The spanish isn't a big deal, the fact that anyone with a boat can come pick up is the real selling point. They don't need to fly it, they just need to provide GPS coords for a deal in the middle of the ocean. A recent bust happened because the boat sank on the way back to PR, rescue teams found them and the drugs. The guy in charge of sailing for this op was a first timer who was paid $10k up front and offered a $90k bonus upon completion (which he never got thanks to his arrest) according to court records. Access to shore on all sides is the big draw for drug smuggling, makes you hard to catch.
